Award.AwardTitle: 2014 MRS Symposium H: Micro/Nano Engineering and Devices for Molecular and Cellular Manipulation, Stimulation and Analysis; Boston, Massachusetts; 30 November - 5 December 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for the partial support of the 2014 MRS Meeting Symposium H on Micro/Nano Engineering and Devices for Molecular and Cellular Manipulation, Stimulation and Analysis. This major international meeting will provide a single forum for discussion of the latest developments in biomedical research in molecular and cellular sensing, stimulation, and characterization. Regular meetings of the key researchers in this field are necessary for the exchange of ideas, information, and state-of-the-art technologies, in order to enable and accelerate advances and breakthroughs in the fields of biomedical science and nanomanufacturing. This international symposium is a key mechanism for linking basic science with engineering towards the development of nanotechnology-enabled biomedical applications, which are of significant importance to the US and world economies. This symposium offers a means for the open exchange of new and previously unpublished scientific ideas. It will include presentations and extended discussions and interactions among international participants. This gathering has been instrumental in the generation and incubation of breakthrough and transformative ideas in many areas of nanotechnology, nanomanufacturing and biomedical engineering.

This award will partially support the participation of junior participants, including undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and early career faculty members. The funds will support the attendance at the conference of 12 participants and undergraduate awards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2014 Materials Research Society (MRS) Meeting Symposium H on Micro/Nano Engineering and Devices for Molecular and Cellular Manipulation, Stimulation and Analysis provides a highly desirable and timely forum for key researchers from around the world to discuss the latest developments in molecular and cellular research, including sensing, stimulation, and characterization. In the three-full-day program, 51 oral talks and 64 posters were presented, which provided essential opportunities for researchers to exchange ideas and initiate collaborations in the field of biomedical devices.  The symposium also effectively linked attendants at different career stages, ranging from well-established scientists (invited speakers), junior researchers, to a large number of young students, which is critical for the education and training of the next-generation personnel for the long-term development of the US and world economies.

The symposium was also a great success in the number of participants, the range of covered topics (12 different subareas in biomedical devices), as well as the extent of support to early career faculty members, outstanding students and postdoctoral fellows, and invited speakers. More than 20 travel awards were given  with the major funding support from the NSF and Air Force Office of Science and Research (AFOSR). The symposium also recognized the most outstanding graduate participants with the Best Presentation/Poster Awards.

The detailed program schedule and abstracts can be found in the link as below:

http://www.mrs.org/fall-2014-program-h/
